problems.solution: Chain the implications: Modus Ponens to get "Q", then "R ∧ S", extract "R" via Simplification, then Modus Ponens to get "T".
Apply De Morgan's to get "¬P ∧ ¬Q", extract "¬P", extract "S" from "R ∧ S", then combine with Conjunction.
Apply Disjunctive Syllogism twice: get "Q ∧ R" and "T", then extract "Q" and combine with "T" via Conjunction.
Combine "P" and "Q" via Conjunction, apply Modus Ponens to get "R ∨ S", then Disjunctive Syllogism with "¬R" to get "S".
Apply Double Negation twice to get "P → Q" and "P", then chain Modus Ponens to get "R ∧ S", finally extract "R".
Get "Q" via Disjunctive Syllogism, then chain Modus Ponens through "R", "S", to "T".
Apply Hypothetical Syllogism to chain "P → Q" and "Q → R" to get "P → R", then use Modus Tollens with "¬R" to get "¬P".
Extract "P ∨ Q" and "R ∨ S" via Simplification, then apply Disjunctive Syllogism twice to get "Q" and "S", combine via Conjunction.
Apply Modus Ponens to get "Q → R", then Modus Ponens with "Q" to get "R", finally Modus Ponens with "R → S" to get "S".
Apply Simplification to separate conjuncts, then De Morgan's on each to get "¬P ∧ ¬Q" and "¬R ∧ ¬S", extract "¬P" and "¬R", combine via Conjunction.
Apply Destructive Dilemma (DN) with premises "(P → Q) ∧ (R → S)" and "¬Q ∨ ¬S" to directly conclude "¬P ∨ ¬R".
Apply Biconditional to Equivalence conversion: "P ↔ Q" is equivalent to "(P ∧ Q) ∨ (¬P ∧ ¬Q)", meaning both are true or both are false.
Expand "P ⊕ Q" to "(P ∨ Q) ∧ ¬(P ∧ Q)", extract "P ∨ Q", then use case analysis: both P and Q lead to R, so R must be true.
Apply Contrapositive (CONV) to "¬Q → ¬R" to get "R → Q", then apply Modus Ponens with "R" to get "Q".
Apply Resolution on "P ∨ Q" and "¬P ∨ R" to get "Q ∨ R", then Resolution with "¬Q ∨ S" to get "R ∨ S".
Use Distributivity or extract components: get "P" and "Q ∨ R", apply Disjunctive Syllogism to get "R", Modus Ponens to get "S", then Conjunction.
Apply Disjunctive Syllogism to get "Q ∧ R", then Simplification twice to extract "Q" and "R", apply Modus Ponens on each to get "S" and "T", finally Conjunction to combine them.
Apply Hypothetical Syllogism twice to chain the implications: "P → Q" and "Q → R" gives "P → R", then "P → R" and "R → S" gives "P → S". Finally, apply Modus Tollens with "¬S" to get "¬P".
Use Addition to get "P ∨ Q" from "P", apply Modus Ponens to get "R", then Modus Ponens again to get "S ∧ T", extract "S".
Expand "P ⊕ Q" to "(P ∨ Q) ∧ ¬(P ∧ Q)", use "¬P" with Disjunctive Syllogism to get "Q", then Conjunction with "¬P".
